questions.text: Your team implements a new AI tool you've never used before. What do you do?

options.text: Stick to old tools and avoid the new AI.
Learn basics on your own or with colleagues; try it on a small task.
Wait for someone to explicitly train you before engaging.
Argue it won't help and suggest skipping it.

questions.text: A client rolls out an AI-driven reporting process. Your first step is…

options.text: Skim the docs later when time allows.
Block 30 minutes to read docs and test with a sample report.
Ask your manager to summarize and tell you what to do.
Ignore until it becomes mandatory.

questions.text: You notice an AI feature inside a tool you already use.

options.text: Disable it so the UI stays the same.
Open a tutorial and test it on low-risk work.
Ask someone else to try it and report back.
Wait for an SOP before touching it.

questions.text: A teammate shares an AI primer course.

options.text: Save the link for someday.
Enroll and set a completion date this week.
Skim only the first lesson.
Decline because courses slow you down.

questions.text: You are asked about your openness to AI-led change.

options.text: Prefer no change to workflows.
Open to change and willing to learn quickly.
Okay with change if fully documented.
Resistant unless mandated.

questions.text: When you hear about a new app that could improve productivity, what best describes you?

options.text: I immediately look it up and try it on a low-risk task.
I wait until others have tried it and use it if it becomes common.
I stick with the tools I already know.
I feel anxious about new tools and avoid them unless required.

questions.text: A new productivity extension promises AI email drafting.

options.text: Install and A/B test on low-risk emails.
Wait for team adoption first.
Ignore because you have a template already.
Avoid extensions entirely.

questions.text: Your main tool ships a major update with release notes.

options.text: Ignore release notes; keep doing things the old way.
Skim and share a relevant tip with the team.
Wait for others to summarize later.
Disable updates until forced.

questions.text: You hear about a tool that summarizes calls automatically.

options.text: Pilot it in one internal meeting.
Bookmark for later review.
Ask someone else to read reviews.
Assume it's hype and move on.

questions.text: You come across an AI article relevant to your role.

options.text: Share a short take with your team channel.
Save it privately.
Skim headline only.
Ignore.

questions.text: You inherit a 12-step manual workflow.

options.text: Document it as-is and continue.
Map steps, group by function, and flag automation candidates.
Ask someone else how they'd do it.
Skip mapping and start executing.

questions.text: Deadlines are tight on a repetitive task.

options.text: Work longer hours to keep up.
Batch tasks and explore an AI template.
Delegate without changing the process.
Push deadlines out.

questions.text: Two teams duplicate data entry in two tools.

options.text: Accept duplication to avoid change risk.
Propose an integration/connector and RACI with SLAs.
Export/import manually weekly.
Let each team manage separately.

questions.text: Error rate increases on a manual QA task.

options.text: Add a second human reviewer.
Introduce an AI checker with human spot-audits.
Accept minor errors to move faster.
Pause the task indefinitely.

questions.text: A request spans multiple teams and tools.

options.text: Handle by email CCs.
Create a shared workflow diagram and RACI.
Ask manager to coordinate.
Let each team manage their part separately.

questions.text: Which statement best describes your experience with ChatGPT or Google Gemini?

options.text: I regularly use them (writing, research, brainstorming) and can guide with prompts.
I've tried them a few times for simple queries.
I've heard of them but haven't really used them.
I don't trust or see a use for them in my work.

questions.text: Best practice for prompting?

options.text: Give one vague sentence.
Provide role, goal, constraints, examples, and format.
Ask the model to "figure it out."
Paste everything you have without structure.

questions.text: Handling sensitive client data with AI:

options.text: Paste raw data into any chatbot.
Redact and use a company-approved, access-controlled environment.
Use a personal account for convenience.
Avoid AI even when a safe option exists.

questions.text: Selecting tools for a task:

options.text: Use one general model for everything.
Choose tools/models based on task (text, vision, agents, automation).
Pick the cheapest option only.
Wait for IT to assign.

questions.text: What does good AI output verification look like?

options.text: Trust the first result.
Cross-check sources and test edge cases before using.
Ask a friend if it seems fine.
Rerun the same prompt once.

questions.text: You must analyze an unfamiliar dataset by end of day.

options.text: Clarify goals, break into parts, and use AI to suggest methods or summaries.
Break it down and do manual analysis only in Excel.
Ask a supervisor to handle it since it's new.
Avoid AI tools and search the web for hours.

questions.text: A solution fails in testing.

options.text: Abandon the approach entirely.
Collect logs, isolate variables, iterate with small changes.
Ask another team to take over.
Ship anyway if it works sometimes.

questions.text: You need to prioritize multiple tasks.

options.text: Do easiest first.
Use impact/effort matrix and deadlines to order work.
Pick what you like most.
Ask someone else to decide.

questions.text: A recurring defect slips into production.

options.text: Create a checklist and an AI guardrail to catch it.
Remind people to be careful.
Assign blame.
Delay releases indefinitely.

questions.text: Stakeholders disagree on requirements.

options.text: Proceed with your interpretation.
Facilitate a brief alignment doc and review.
Wait until they agree.
Build two versions.

questions.text: Explaining an AI workflow to a non-technical client looks like…

options.text: Use jargon; they'll learn.
Use plain language, diagrams, and a short example.
Send a long whitepaper.
Ask someone else to present.

questions.text: Handing off a process to a teammate requires…

options.text: Explain verbally once.
A concise SOP with screenshots/templates.
A long video without chapters.
Let them figure it out.

questions.text: A client questions AI accuracy; you…

options.text: Get defensive.
Acknowledge limits; describe controls and QC steps.
Say it's perfect now.
Avoid answering.

questions.text: Proposing automation changes, you provide…

options.text: Only the idea.
Before/after metrics and a rollout plan.
A meme.
Ask manager to sell it.

questions.text: Presenting to executives vs. engineers, you…

options.text: Reuse one deck for speed.
Tailor outcomes/risks for execs and technical steps for engineers.
Send a long whitepaper to both.
Rely on jargon for speed.

questions.text: You receive constructive feedback on your AI prompts.

options.text: Defend your approach.
Thank them and iterate on a new version.
Ignore unless mandated.
Ask them to write the prompts instead.

questions.text: A pilot fails to reach expected ROI.

options.text: Cancel AI initiatives.
Run a retro; adjust scope and try again.
Hide the results.
Blame the tool.

questions.text: You're assigned a stretch learning goal (e.g., Level 2 → 3).

options.text: Decline due to workload.
Create a learning plan with milestones.
Skim a video and call it done.
Ask to postpone indefinitely.

questions.text: A colleague shares a better workflow you didn't know.

options.text: Ignore to avoid rework.
Adopt it and credit them in the SOP.
Use it silently.
Argue the old way is fine.

questions.text: You're asked to mentor a junior on AI basics.

options.text: Decline; not your job.
Share resources and review their first attempts.
Point them to a link only.
Tell them to ask someone else.
